title: Wayne Rooney backs Liverpool to beat Manchester City to Premier League title
text:
Liverpool edged past Leicester to maintain their 100 per cent Premier League record (Picture: Getty)

Manchester United great Wayne Rooney has backed Liverpool to end their painful 30-year wait and beat Manchester City to the Premier League title this season.

James Milner converted a controversial last-gasp penalty against Leicester to maintain Liverpool’s 100 per cent record in the English top flight, with eight wins from their opening eight matches.

City, meanwhile, looking to defend their 2018/19 crown, are eight points adrift of Liverpool in second place ahead of their clash with Wolves on Sunday.

Last month, Norwich proved that City can be beaten with a stunning 3-2 victory at Carrow Road and Rooney believes Liverpool have made ground on Pep Guardiola’s champions this term.

Rooney has tipped Klopp’s side to lift the Premier League trophy (Picture: Getty)

Despite his ties to bitter rivals Everton, the ex-England striker told IFL TV: ‘In my opinion, Liverpool look the strongest.

‘Manchester City are a fantastic team.

‘I think Liverpool have improved on last year, whereas City have stayed at that level of great consistency, so I think Liverpool.’

In the aftermath of Liverpool’s narrow win over Leicester, Jurgen fumed at Hamza Choudhury’s ‘dangerous as hell’ tackle on Mohamed Salah in the dying moments at Anfield.

Though referee Chris Kavanagh booked Choudhury for the late challenge, Klopp clearly felt the Leicester midfielder should have been sent off.

‘It was a challenge which I don’t understand,’ the German said.

‘I don’t understand how he can do it because the ball is far away. If you bring down a player in full sprint, when the ball is not around, it is for me only one colour. It’s dangerous as hell.’

He added: ‘I don’t want to cause the boy any problems but he has to calm down. He is a super player, super development in the last two years. But these kind of challenges? No.

‘If you are quick someone needs to make sure that not everything is allowed to bring you down. The ball is not even close.

‘I don’t need to be a football manager to know this can cause serious injury. I only need two eyes.’
